audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the famous equation E=mc², touching upon the relationship between energy and mass and the possibility of creating mass, but notes twice the energy is actually needed. He then signals a shift in topic with "but what I want to get into". He adds there is a "short detour" into pair production and annihilation. Afterwards, there is a brief percussive sound effect.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing particle physics, noting the need to produce not only a particle, but also its antiparticle, such as the positron of an electron, and how these behave oppositely in electric and magnetic fields. He continues, describing a cloud chamber saturated with water vapor, and how charged particles leave tracks as water droplets form when a magnetic field is applied. The speaker describes how scientists used this setup to study particle movement, and how Carl Anderson discovered positively charged particles in cosmic rays with significantly lower mass than protons, around twice the mass of an electron. He then refers to a figure from 1932 which won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1936, showing the positron as a long line through the middle.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing better detectors and production on demand and mentions CERN and electron-positron production. The speaker's tone is informational. He explains that a photon splits into an electron and an anti-electron and describes the equation E=mc^2. He continues to provide an example of turning a kilogram of mass into pure energy.

A male speaker with an analytical tone begins by discussing "Fat Man," the bomb dropped on Nagasaki, mentioning it had about "9 trillion joules." He states the need for "10,000 of them" to match a bottle of water and then sarcastically refers to the difficulty of finding "anti-water." He then poses the question of how we could possibly use the concept of the equation E=mc². Before he starts explaining, he cautions that he is going to make a few things clear.

The clip begins with one male speaker describing "E equals MC squared," then transitions to explaining an electron volt. He defines this unit as the "energy an electron gets when it is accelerated through 1 volt of potential difference." He continues to explain that a mega electron volt is a million electron volts. The same speaker then states the mass of different particles, including the electron, proton, neutron, and deuterium nucleus.

The audio clip features a single male speaker in a conversational tone discussing the composition of deuterium and its mass. He explains that the mass of a deuterium atom is less than the combined mass of a proton and a neutron, introducing the concept of binding energy and how mass and energy are related. The speaker further explains that energy must be put back into the system to separate it into the component parts, and this process is the basis of how nuclear fusion and fission work.

The audio clip starts with one male speaker explaining nuclear fusion, describing the process of pushing together atoms, protons, and neutrons to form a new atom. He provides the example of fusing deuterium nuclei to form a helium nuclei and the energy release associated with it. He speaks calmly, explaining that energy release decreases with more particles, but the binding energy increases, up to a point, after which, it decreases. He talks about the process of nuclear fission. He emphasizes that both fusion and fission can happen at any binding energy, but energy is only released in a higher binding energy state. He presents an example of uranium 238 fissioning into an alpha particle and thorium 234. Continuing in the same calm and explanatory tone, the speaker moves on to describe the mass difference between protons and neutrons, stating that neutrons have more energy and can decay into a proton, electron and anti-electron neutrino. He talks about neutron decay and mentions that neutrons have a half-life of about 15 minutes. He notes that after 15 minutes there is a 50% chance that a neutron has changed into a proton. He concludes the description with a more technical explanation of how the wave function of the neutron changes to a superposition of both.
The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that something marks the end of part one. He announces they will be covering nuclear fission in part two. The speaker's tone is informative.
